executive_summary: Over the past five years, the Dollar and Variety Stores industry has experienced significant changes. High-income consumers have been more attracted to these stores because of their enhanced value perception, especially amid economic uncertainties. Stores have significantly increased the diversity of their product offerings, resulting in an expanded customer base. Strategic locations in higher-income neighborhoods and high-traffic areas have accelerated their appeal to wealthier customers. Inflationary trends, particularly in the food sector, have boosted demand for groceries at dollar and variety stores as consumers look for more affordable shopping options.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Dollar and Variety Stores industry have seen an increased influx of high-income consumers over the past five years because of the store's enhanced value perception. Economic uncertainties led even financially stable consumers to explore budget-saving routes, helping these stores shed the stigma of being just discount retailers.

The combination of these trends has driven growth. Industry revenue is expected to climb at a CAGR of 4.7% to $124.9 billion, including an expected rise of 0.3% in 2024 alone, with profit set to account for 4.4% of revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Inflation Has Increased Demand for Groceries
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A surge in inflation, particularly in the food sector, has significantly driven up demand for groceries at dollar and variety stores. With the rising cost of living, more consumers are turning to these stores to get more value for their money.

Dollar stores have expanded their product offerings to include a mix of top-brand and private-label goods across various product categories. While this has attracted a larger customer base, it has also led to minor price hikes among some dollar stores.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-Commerce Expansion and Partnerships Have Contributed to Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dollar and variety stores have expanded into e-commerce to keep up with changing consumer shopping behaviors. Online platforms increase their customer reach and offer an alternative to in-store shopping, attracting a broader consumer base.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovative Store Concepts Will Attract More Consumers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Dollar and variety stores will increasingly focus on expanding their product offerings and redesigning store layouts and aesthetics to attract a larger consumer base.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Internal and External Competition Will Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Low economic barriers to entry into the industry will cause competition to expand among dollar and variety stores over the next five years. To remain competitive, stores will diversify their product range, invest in an improved shopping experience and promote customer loyalty programs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Dollar and Variety Stores Will Expand Into Underserved Areas
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition from larger retailers continues to grow, dollar and variety stores will expand into underserved areas that competitors often overlook. These areas provide a less competitive environment and can foster a steady inflow of loyal customers.

The latest war between Israel and Hamas has contributed to global supply chain disruptions, which has sparked concern about spiking fuel prices. A potential rise in fuel costs over the next five years will increase shipping and operational costs for dollar and variety stores.

industry_definition: This Dollar and Variety Stores industry retails general merchandise, such as apparel, automotive parts, dry goods, hardware, groceries, and home furnishings. Typically, industry operators retail these goods at discounted prices.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: National unemployment rate
threats: Low Outlier Growth: Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Price and product selection are the biggest competitive factors between dollar and variety stores. Because customers are seeking low-priced items, stores that can offer the lowest price have an advantage.
Supercenters and other mass retailers are external competition for dollar and variety stores. These stores offer a similar range of products and are perceived as being of higher quality.
The Dollar and Variety Stores industry has benefited from volatile economic conditions over the past five years. As more consumers became price-sensitive, demand for dollar stores grew.
Competition will increase over the next five years. Larger retailers that can offer similar products at competitive pricing will threaten dollar and variety stores.
Dollar General is the largest dollar and variety store. The company is continuing to gain market share by opening new stores and increasing its product portfolio.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes consumers from households with incomes of $40,000 or less annually. Consumers in this demographic are the largest market for dollar and variety stores. Households earning below $40,000 annually seek cost-effective shopping options to manage their budget efficiently. Dollar and variety stores offer a wide range of products at significantly affordable prices, making them an ideal shopping destination for lower-income households.

This segment includes consumers who earn between $40,001 and $99,999 annually. Over the past five years, this segment's share of revenue has increased as consumers of this income demographic opt for the value of industry products. During uncertain economic times, consumers in this demographic tighten their budgets and seek cost-effective solutions for everyday items, increasing their demand for dollar and variety stores.

This segment includes consumers with incomes over $100,000. Over the past five years, this segment has slightly expanded as a share of total industry revenue, as price-savvy shopping has become increasingly popular. Rising inflation rates have led even higher-income individuals to seek out dollar and variety stores for their affordable offerings. Dollar and variety stores have increasingly been diversifying and upgrading their product selection to attract high-income consumers.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: When disposable incomes rise, consumers spend more on higher-end products, diminishing dollar store sales. Conversely, in tighter economic conditions, shoppers flock to these stores seeking affordable essentials, driving up industry performance. So dollar stores generally thrive during economic downturns while a rise in disposable income poses a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is home to the largest share of dollar and variety stores establishments compared to its population share. Income levels in the Southeast region tend to be lower compared to other parts of the US. Dollar and variety stores offer a wide range of low-cost products, making them a popular choice for budget-conscious households in these areas.

The Great Lakes region in the US has a high population. Large populations provide a larger customer base that can help to generate steadier sales for dollar and variety stores. The region also has a large number of lower-income and middle-class consumers. Dollar and variety stores typically offer affordable products that cater to these demographics, making the region an ideal location for such businesses. The Great Lakes region is well-served by transportation networks like highways, railways and ports. This logistical advantage makes it easier for stores to receive inventory and maintain an adequate supply of goods.

The Mid-Atlantic region constitutes a significant population across several densely populated states, representing a broad customer base for dollar and variety stores ensuring steady consumer traffic and sales. While the region has some of the highest median household incomes in the country, there is still demand for bargain shopping. Also, dollar and variety stores have expanded their product offerings to appeal to higher-income consumers. The cost of living is relatively high in the Mid-Atlantic region, which can increase the appeal of dollar and variety stores.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Contains details for the federal minimum wage, currently $7.25/hour. Also contains regulations for businesses employing children under 18, covering wages, work hours and tasks.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration
regulations_points.regulation_description: Promotes safe working environments, with guidelines on safety equipment, hazardous materials, building design/maintenance, medical protocols etc. Dollar stores must adhere to avoid fines.
Sets safety standards for consumer products like toys, electronics and household items sold at dollar stores. Compliance is crucial to avoid penalties, recalls and reputation damage.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The dollar and variety stores industry is mature.
The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Price and product selection are the biggest competitive factors between dollar and variety stores. Because customers are seeking low-priced items, stores that can offer the lowest price have an advantage.
Supercenters and other mass retailers are external competition for dollar and variety stores. These stores offer a similar range of products and are perceived as being of higher quality.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large stores benefit from economies of scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: Economies of scale allow these operators to offer a wide variety of products at a low cost. Also, strong brand recognition benefits large stores as more consumers are driven to their establishments.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Smaller stores capitalize on niche offerings
concentration_points.concentration_description: While the industry is concentrated at the top, the remaining share of the market is mainly composed of small- to medium-sized operators catering to localized demand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The business model revolves around offering a wide selection of products at low prices, often in smaller sizes or quantities. To maintain this breadth of inventory, stores must make frequent and broad-ranging purchases from suppliers, making purchases the most significant expense.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Necessary Labor Keeps Wages a Main Expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As a retail industry, dollar and variety stores are labor-intensive for daily operations like assisting customers, maintaining store displays and monitoring inventory. Over the past five years, new entrants have heightened general labor competition, keeping wages a major expense.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Like most retailing industries, the majority of operational costs are devoted to the payment of wages rather than capital equipment. Employees are needed for management, customer service, stocking shelves and other daily tasks.

volatility_points.volatility_description: During economic downturns, consumers turn to dollar and variety stores for affordable alternatives, boosting sales and providing a stable revenue stream. These stores stock essential items, ensuring continued consumer demand.

Intense competition from big-box retailers, supermarkets and e-commerce giants leads to price wars, squeezing profit and making revenue streams less predictable. Competitors frequently introduce new products/services/technologies, compelling dollar stores to adapt swiftly, leading to inconsistent investment and revenue patterns.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: By establishing online storefronts, dollar and variety stores can reach a wider customer base beyond their physical locations, driving higher sales and customer satisfaction. Stores that can seamlessly integrate online and offline shopping enhance the customer experience.

Developing private label brands allows stores to offer exclusive products at lower prices, enhancing profit while maintaining affordability. Private labels enable quick adaptation to market trends and customer preferences, and greater control over product quality.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: While dollar and variety stores retail a variety of consumer goods, they hold a niche position in the retail sectors since these products are sold at low and discounted prices.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The industry primarily functions counter-cyclically to the economy. When the poverty rate increases, more consumers look to cut costs by shopping at these low-price establishments.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: The industry has benefited from a decline in input costs since a large portion of the goods that industry retailers sell are imported. In recent years, the dollar has gained value in oversees markets, making imports more affordable.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Merger and acquisition activity is significant in this industry. This included Dollar Tree's large Family Dollar acquisition.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Point-of-sale systems have become increasingly common in this industry, especially with larger chains with more market share.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales in recent years?
FAQs.answer: While online sales have somewhat pressured demand for this brick-and-mortar retail industry, dollar and variety stores offer fast and easy access to consumers that is unavailable with e-tailers.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Various retail industry associations support operators in this retail industry, including the National Retail Federation and the American Apparel and Footwear Association.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Large stores may have in-house compliance teams that ensure they are up to date with regulations. Small dollar and variety stores may rely on external support, like industry associations.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for cash flow seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Cash flow is not generally impacted by seasons since products sold at industry establishments are considered to be essentials.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Dollar and variety stores rarely purchase new equipment since very few capital expenses are required for this retail industry.

FAQs.question: How do you track the most popular products in your stores? What management systems do you have in place to limit overstock?
FAQs.answer: Dollar and variety stores need to have stringent stock control measures to ensure that popular items are reordered, low-selling stock is disposed of and sufficient product lines are available.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are competitive? How do your products compare with those offered at non-industry stores?
FAQs.answer: The major basis of competition in this industry is price, so players must ensure that pricing is competitive and represents value to consumers.

FAQs.question: How do you market your store and products to customers? Who do you target with your ads?
FAQs.answer: Successful players will drive revenue growth through effective advertising and marketing initiatives.

FAQs.question: Who are the primary demographics you target? Have you been able to attract customers to your establishment as opposed to non-industry alternatives?
FAQs.answer: Food and household essentials supplied by this industry compete with those offered by large-format retailers, including Walmart and discount wholesale stores like Costco.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of the national unemployment rate?
FAQs.answer: The unemployment rate is positively correlated to sales at dollar and variety stores. When unemployment rises, budget-conscious consumers are more likely to shop at dollar and variety stores.

FAQs.question: Are your stores located in densely populated areas? Are you prepared to handle an influx of more potential customers as population grows?
FAQs.answer: As the population increases, so does the number of potential industry customers. Population growth in specific regions is an important indicator of future establishment growth, as the number of stores is generally related to an area's population.
